Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continuation of the XENON Dark Matter Search at LNGS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics with profound implications for our view of the Universe. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays.

The identification of Dark Matter (DM) poses a challenge that is being addressed with a variety of complementary approaches and technologies. The direct search for DM with the XENON project at the Gran Sasso laboratory promises an extremely cost-efficient approach to cover vast regions of expected DM parameter space. This award will enable the US groups in XENON to participate in the operations and data analysis of XENON100 well into 2015 when the start of the scientific program with XENON1T is expected. With a strong presence at Gran Sasso, the US groups will maintain a leading role in the commissioning and operation of XENON1T.

Broader Impacts:
A number of students as well as post-doctoral researchers are involved in the XENON project at universities across the US. They are exposed to a variety of subjects in fundamental physics and cosmology, and trained in the development and application of state-of-the-art technologies, preparing them to become future leaders in the field. The instrumentation and techniques used in XENON are relevant to a wide range of applications, from areas in homeland security and medical imaging, to the analysis and statistical treatment of large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is ample evidence that the Universe is actually dominated by an entirely unknown form of matter, called Dark Matter. However, it is at this stage entirely unknown what Dark Matter actually consists of. To find out, this grant supported the participation of the Purdue group on the international XENON collaboration. This collaboration runs two world-leading experiments to directly search for signals from Dark Matter, the XENON100 and XENON1T detectors. Both detectors are located in the Gran Sasso underground laboratory in central Italy to shield them from Cosmic Radiation, and both are time projection chambers filled with liquid xenon and read out by arrays of Photomultiplier Tubes.

The Purdue PI has led analyses in search for signatures from somewhat unconventional Dark Matter particle candidates, as published in Science. More than a dozen qualitatively different searches for Dark Matter were performed using the XENON100 experiment. This included searches for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) of various kinds, for Axions and Axion-like particles, as well as for particular models such as leptophilic or inelastic Dark Matter. However, no Dark Matter signals could so far be found in these data sets.

The XENON collaboration therefore built the enhanced XENON1T detector which will surpass the sensitivity of XENON100 by at least two orders of magnitude. For that experiment in particular, the Purdue group invented and characterized novel calibration methods which enabled the Dark Matter search of XENON1T or even-larger, future detectors. Beyond XENON1T, these novel methods can be used in other areas of basic research as well as in areas of radiation detection. The Purdue group also established that the XENON1T detector is sensitive to neutrino-induced signals from supernova explosion from across our entire Milky Way Galaxy.

Almost 100 undergraduate students were involved during the duration of this grant in the research conducted at the Purdue Dark Mater lab. Four graduate students graduated with this research and two postdoctoral associates were supported at Purdue. The Purdue group is very active in outreach, runs the xenon1t.org website and is active on twitter @XENON1T. We greatly welcome your questions, feedback, and comments.
